title: PCT 32: The man who wore red
author: Mrs. Maggie Achenam

sentences.original: êkwah kotak nâpêw mâmaskâc êsah kîh-miywêyihtam êh-mihkosîhot.
sentences.text: êkwa kotak nâpêw mâmaskâc êsa kî-miywêyihtam ê-mihkosihot
sentences.english: Now, there was another man, the story goes, who greatly liked to wear red clothes.
Once when he dressed up, his belt was red,
and red yarn he had for his ammunition-bag;
he wore red flannel breeches;
a red feather was on his hat.

sentences.original: êkwah nisto-pipon isiyihkâtêwah kayâs ayîsiyiniwak ê-kîh-wiyâhtâcik;
sentences.text: êkwa nisto-pipon isiyîhkâtêwa kayâs ayîsiyiniwak ê-kî-wiyâhtâcik
sentences.english: And 'three-year' were called some things which the old-time people wore;
sentences.footnote: LB has a footnote number on {nisto-pipon}, but no footnote.

sentences.english: one of these also he had on, as he hunted.

sentences.original: êkwah itê nipahêw pêyak mostoswak; wiyanihêw.
sentences.text: êkwa itê nipahêw pêyak mostoswak wiyanihêw
sentences.english: Then over there he killed a buffalo; he set about skinning and cutting it up.

sentences.original: mâkwâc êh-wiyanihât, kêtahtawê êh-tasôt, pôt ôh ôtah kâ-nîpawiyit ayîsiyiniwah, nîpiminânah êh-tahkonamiyit, namoya êh-nîpiwiyikih.
sentences.text: mêkwâc ê-wiyanihât kêtahtawê ê-tasot pôti ôhi ôta kâ-nîpawiyit ayîsiyiniwa nîpiminâna ê-tahkonamiyit namôya ê-nîpîwiyiki
sentences.english: While he was cleaning it, at one time, as he straightened up, there stood a man holding some cranberries without leaves.
“Here!” this person said to him.
He did not want to take them;

sentences.original: kostêw, pêyak pikô oskîsikoyiw oskahtikoyihk ê-oskîsikoyit.
sentences.text: kostêw pêyak piko oskîsikoyiw oskahtikoyihk ê-oskîsikoyit
sentences.english: he feared him, for he had only one eye, on his forehead.
Like a round dish, so big was that man's eye;
that was why he feared him.
He ran away.

sentences.original: mâkwâc êh-pimâmot, kêtahtawê k-ôtihtât ominahôwinah; pôt ôhi kêyâpic êkotah kîh-nîpawiyiwah.
sentences.text: mêkwâc ê-pimâmot kêtahtawê kâ-otihtât ominahôwina pôti ôhi kêyâpic êkota kî-nîpawiyiwa
sentences.english: As he fled, lo, he came again to the game he had killed, and there was that person standing again.
Again he ran away.
Soon again he came running to that place.
Again he ran away.

sentences.original: nêwâw êh-takopahtât êkotah, êkwah namoya kiskisiw.
sentences.text: nêwâw ê-takopahtât êkota êkwa namôya kiskisiw
sentences.english: When he had ran into that place four times, he fainted.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê êh-wâpaniyik, kîkisêpâ kiskisiw, kêkâc êh-nipit, êh-kipitonêhpisot opîhtaskatêwânah.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê ê-wâpaniyik kîkisêpâ kiskisiw kêkâc ê-nipit ê-kipitonêhpisot opîhtaskatêwâna
sentences.english: When day broke, he came to his senses, almost dead, his mouth tied shut with the thongs of his powder-horn.
He arose.
He untied himself.
He was all naked; he had not a thing on his body.
Then he went home.
When he arrived, a ceremonial meal was prepared for him.
He made inquiry.

sentences.original: kîh-âcimot êh-isi-wâpahtahk, maht niya nkah-otinên, itwêyiwah kotak âyîsiyiniwah.
sentences.english: When he had told his experience, “Why, I should have taken them,” said the other people.

sentences.original: êkwah âtiht, sâkôtêyimik êkâ tit-ôtinahk, itwêwak âtiht ayîsiyiniwak.
sentences.english: And some, “That person frightened him out of taking them,” said some people.
That is the way this is told.
